Racism in [[South Africa]] is still prevalent.{{Cite web|url=http://www.univie.ac.at/ecco/stichproben/Nr6_Interview_Moleah.pdf|format=PDF|title=Interview with Prof. Alfred Tokollo Moleah, South African Ambassador to Vienna |last=Englert|first=Birgit|publisher=Universität Wien|accessdate=2008-11-19}} The end of [[South Africa under apartheid|apartheid]] might have removed the legal framework allowing [[institutionalised racism]], however, racism in South Africa both predates and encompasses more than just the institutionalised racism of apartheid ==Colonial racism== The establishment of the [[Dutch East India Company]] settlement at the [[Cape of Good Hope]] in 1652 brought with it the established slave labor practices of the company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iziko.org.za/sh/resources/slavery/slavery_world.html|title=Slavery at the Cape|publisher=Iziko Museums of Cape Town|accessdate=2008-11-19}} Many of these slaves were imported from the company's more established settlements in India and the East Indies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/solidarity/indiasa3.html|title=Indian Slaves in South Africa|publisher=[[African National Congress]]|accessdate=2008-11-19 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080622023927/http://www.anc.org.za/ancdocs/history/solidarity/indiasa3.html |archivedate = 2008-06-22}} Slavery was by no means restricted to the European slave trade. During the [[Difaqane]], the [[Zulu Kingdom|Zulu]] under [[Shaka]] overran many smaller tribes and enslaved them.{{Cite web|url=http://www.isic.org/sisp/index.htm?fx=destination&loc_id=131114§ion=culture|title=Destinations: South Africa - Pre 20th Century History|publisher=International Student Travel Conveduration|accessdate=2008-11-20}} Slavery in South Africa was officially [[Abolitionism|abolished]] in 1833 with the [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833|Slavery Abolition Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.anti-slaverysociety.addr.com/huk-1833act.htm|title=Slavery Abolition Act 1833|date=1833-10-29|publisher=Houses of Parliament, Palace of Westminster, London.|accessdate=2008-11-19}} There are many examples of racism and discriminatory practices during the colonial period, such as the allocation of rations during the [[Siege of Ladysmith]] {{quote|For Whites—Biscuit, 1/4 lb.; Maize meal, 3 oz.
For Indians and Kaffirs(Coloureds)—Maize meal, 8 oz.
Europeans—Fresh meat, 1 lb.
Kaffirs—Fresh meat, 1-1/4 lbs. (Chiefly horseflesh.)
For White men—Coffee or tea, 1/12 oz.; pepper, 1/64 oz.; salt, 1/3 oz.; sugar, 1 oz.; mustard, 1/20 oz.; Vinegar, 1/12 gill.
For Indians—a little rice.| H. W. Nevinson {{Gutenberg|no=16603|name=Ladysmith, The Diary of a Siege by Henry W. Nevinson}}}} Even [[Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi|Gandhi]], who worked to eradicate racism—and in particular racism that affected the Indian communities in South Africa—was prone to making racist remarks during this period. In one of his [[Gandhi#Early South African articles|early articles]] for the ''[[Indian Opinion]]'', he wrote: {{quote|source=|Kaffirs are as a rule uncivilised—the convicts even more so. They are troublesome, very dirty and live almost like animals.|Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi {{Cite book|title=The Collected Works of Mahatma Gandhi|volume=8|pages=199}} }} ==Apartheid racism== {{See also|South Africa under apartheid}} Apartheid (Afrikaans pronunciation: {{IPA-af|aˈpartɦəit|}}; an Afrikaans word meaning "separateness", or "the state of being apart", literally "apart-hood") was a system of racial segregation in South Africa enforced through legislation by the National Party (NP), the governing party from 1948 to 1994. Under apartheid, the rights, associations, and movements of the majority black inhabitants and other ethnic groups were curtailed, and white minority rule was maintained. Apartheid was developed after World War II by the [[Afrikaners|Afrikaner]]-dominated National Party and Broederbond organizations. The ideology was also enforced in South West Africa, which was administered by South Africa under a League of Nations mandate (revoked in 1966 via United Nations Resolution 2145), until it gained independence as Namibia in 1990. By extension, the term is currently used for forms of systematic segregation established by the state authority in a country against the social and civil rights of a certain group of citizens due to ethnic prejudices. == Post-Apartheid racism == Racial populism and anti-white sentiment is an increasing worry in post-Apartheid South Africa. [[Afrobarometer]] research has indicated that perceptions of discrimination have increased significantly since 2011 amongst citizens from minority race groups, especially among those of Indian ethnicity.{{Cite journal|last=Lekalake|first=Rorisang|last2=Nkomo|first2=Sibusiso|date=2016-04-20|title=South Africans generally tolerant but report racial discrimination by employers and courts|url=http://afrobarometer.org/sites/default/files/publications/Dispatches/ab_r6_dispatchno84-south-africa-discrimination.pdf|journal=The Institute for Justice and Reconciliation|volume=84|pages=1}} According to [[R. W. Johnson|R.W. Johnson]], although post-Apartheid South Africa initially strove to be a non-racial dispensation under President [[Nelson Mandela]], subsequent presidents [[Thabo Mbeki]] and [[Jacob Zuma]] both mobilised anti-white sentiment in order to maintain political power.{{Cite web|url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/opinion/south-africas-racial-mania|title=South Africa's racial
